Likewise, the axial field  $(\mathbf{B}_A)$  of a bar magnet for  $r >> l$  is:

$$
\mathbf {B} _ {A} = \frac {\mu_ {0}}{4 \pi} \frac {2 \mathbf {m}}{r ^ {3}} \tag {5.5}
$$

Equation (5.5) is just Eq. (5.1) in the vector form. Table 5.1 summarises the analogy between electric and magnetic dipoles.

TABLE 5.1 THE DIPOLE ANALOGY

|   | Electrostatics | Magnetism  |
| --- | --- | --- |
|  Dipole moment | 1/ε0 | μ0  |
|  Equatorial Field for a short dipole | p | m  |
|  Axial Field for a short dipole | -p/4πε0r3 | -μ0m / 4πr3  |
|  External Field: torque | 2p/4πε0r3 | μ02m / 4πr3  |
|  External Field: Energy | p × E | m × B  |
|   | -p·E | -m·B  |
summary: The axial field (B_A) of a bar magnet for r >> l is given by Eq. (5.5), which is just Eq. (5.1) in the vector form. Table 5.1 summarizes the analogy between electric and magnetic dipoles.
